comments.commentBody:
My son started Kindergarten at the age of four at an International IB school in India, after he had been attending pre-school since the age of 2 1/2. He was born in December 2004. Had we been at home in the states at the time, he would have been forced to wait the additional year. He is now about to finish 1st grade at the age of six (youngest in his class) and he is thriving. He reads at a near 3rd grade level and is in the top three students in his class in math and English, and he receives exemplary marks in art. Many of his school friends have already turned seven. He doesn't have any issues with the 'older' kids other than the usual issues that children that age experience with each other.

In my son's case, starting Kindergarten a year earlier was a good decision. He was ready. One of things that I worry about when we return home to the states is that the schools will want him to repeat a grade simply due to his age rather than his ability. I think that a child's ability is what should be considered when a child begins school. Whether or not they have been prepared for Kindergarten makes all of the difference, not merely the age of the child. Many children are ready at age four. I don't think my child is an exception to the rule.

God bless you Kid and your wife and family.

Hang in there Big Guy. Many people praying for you never rooted for the Mets or Expos. They simply know class when they see it.
Well written and expressed comment, Highgunner.  I totally agree with you.

Hooray!  Racehorses should race; kudos to Team Valor and Graham Motion for their decision.  I hope Animal Kingdom wins the Belmont.  His trainer represents some of the best qualities of the sport and I wish him success and satisfaction now and for many years.  I also hope AK does some training over the Belmont surface before the big race.

I hope Federer loses soon. Nothing's worse for this tennis and this blog if he keeps winning without being challenged. The NYT bloggers are so biased for the arrogant Swiss they'd be more than happy to swoon over him for the rest of the week under the guise of "expert tennis analysis" if there were no Djokovic or Nadal to stop him.
Tsonga should have won that third set and the match. He needs to find a coach.
definitely half-empty...

I like him to win too, but Federer has often played some very good matches early on in the tournaments the past year or two, only to fizzle out later, so I am not going to be holding my breath. The likelihood of him having to go through Djokovic/Potro and Nadal on clay to win is very slim indeed.
Huh? Is this a Suess parable? or reality?

Have many LEDs in my house from YSDI LED. Their website http://www.yoursender.com has detailed information and specs about their products and will more than likely answer most questions. Their prices are far more competitive than the aforementioned retail giants and the 3-year warranty for their bulbs is certainly an added bonus.
Usually things worth doing, such as changing over from incandescents to LEDs, aren’t always easy, however, in the long run it almost always pays off.

I never knew there were districts that still had this practice until we moved to Michigan and I was registering my son as an older 5 year old for kindergarten. Both my boys are October babies and as it turned out my son had "missed" the opportunity for the 4 year old entrance...which was perfectly fine since he had had some delays and truly needed extra time... However my boys are very different from each other and I was very much looking forward to sending the younger one this coming fall. Any reservations I had with him were based on peer pressure and not on fear of his performance (his development has always been more predictable and consistently on time or early). However I did cave in a little, because I opted out of registering for the full day program and went for a half day option specifically for older 4's entering the school system. Even though he would have to attend a different school from my 2nd grader it seemed like a happy medium and to be frank, I was just thrilled to not have to pay for a few hours of childcare...

But just weeks after agreements had been made and paths were cleared I'm here in Seattle and my son has lost the option for either public kindergarten or preschool program. I'm looking at having to pay $1200-1500 a month for a comparable private program, if we can even get into any, as the wait list are rather long and we're new... It's turning out to be a real issue and not one I had expected to encounter on our arrival here.

What is it about Princeton that its economists ignore the effects of the 2001-2002 recession on revenue, and instead blame only the Bush tax cuts?

Its plain from the chart that the deficit in 2007 was very manageable (it was only about $160 billion) and decreasing. Yet you present a chart showing the Bush tax cuts as responsible for $700 billion in deficits in 2019. The same tax cuts cause 4 times as much of a deficit 12 years later? That's absurd on the face of it. Clearly there are other forces at work here.

Blame the 2008-2009 recession all on George Bush if it makes you happy, but pinning the majority of future deficits on the 2001 and 2003 tax cuts is hogwash.

The fear is these dictators will be replaced with even more right wing conservative radical religious dictators. Everyone talks about the middle east gaining democracy but they have no expereince or history of democracy. When were there ever free and fair elections in the middle east.
The sooner we all develop and put into place renewable energy sources the sooner we can get off the oil bandwagon and at least not be dealing with immoral regimes because we need the oil.
Are the Saudi Arabians developing renewable energy sources in anticipation of the time when the oil gets too expensive or runs out?? With all their money they should be getting ready to sell us the new energy technology instead of making snow in the middle of the desert.

My birthday is in September. At age five, I was intellectually ready for kindergarten, and I had been in pre-school, but I emotionally would have benefited from another year at home. My cousins have November and December boys who all were allowed that extra time to mature, and all three are thriving.

Some children might be ready earlier, especially if the school and social network are supportive, but I think the average late-birthday child probably ought to start school later rather than earlier. There is plenty of time; no need to rush.

Parents ought to be doing a lot of that early prep work at home, anyway. HeadStart style programs and pre-school can help bridge the gap.

As a remedial teacher, I see adults who struggle with the simplest concepts because of gaps in their early schooling. It is better to take the time to establish a good foundation, and that can't be done if the child is worrying about fitting in or just can't do the work due to developmental delay.

I believe Barca will, as others have pointed out, win the possession game in the neighborhood of about 60/40, or even 70/30. That being said, Man Utd would deploy efficient counter-attack; typical of trademark English football. Man Utd would be down 1-0 and 2-1 but eventually would tie the score late in the regulation for penalty shootout to decide the match. 4-3 advantage to Man Utd.

It is surprising to me how many people have said [in support of sending 4yo's to kindergarten] that they themselves or their children would be "bored" at home, and the solution is to send them to school no matter their age. Something is desperately wrong with all this "boredom".
How do homeschooled children and "unschooled" children manage to finish at the top of their classes and win prestigious national competitions like spelling bees? I can guarantee that these kids found plenty of stimulation at home with books, puzzles, playing outside, doing crafts and generally finding plenty to occupy themselves, despite the fact that their parents have opted out of traditional schooling. Kids who complain of boredom should be given the phrase that my mom used to say.."If you are bored, I will FIND something for you to do!" Myself and my 4 siblings learned never to say "I'm bored" or sure as sure, you were busy doing chores moments later.
My own opinion is that children who watch TV and play Video games have "unlearned" the art of creative play and need time to relearn this amazing gift that they have inborn.

Hey Ms. Karmel,
Girls can handle a charcoal fire, can't they?

Hey, Mr. Reporter, why is the company called Weber if it was founded by George Stephen?

Inquiring minds want to know.

Maybe back in 1954 he predicted that something would come along called the Internetter and he could post information about his product on a Weber-site.

Maybe not.

Sorry.

I teach remedial adult math. The simpler and more direct the visual, the better the average person will be able to understand it. A plate half-covered by produce is much easier to comprehend than the abstraction of the pyramid. I look forward to seeing what they've come up with (cross fingers).

If Michelle Obama would prevail upon her husband to allow farmers to sell fruits and vegetables on the side then  wholesome food would be more affordable and more available.  Government regulations are depriving the people of wholesome food.

We should all be proud of the work that Michelle Obama is doing here. It's a shame that she has been the brunt of the mean-spirited and small-minded attacks from conservatives generally, but especially on this issue which has far reaching economic and environmental repercussions.

Keep up the great work, Michelle.

It sounds better than the pyramid, but let's face it. Most people know which foods are healthy and which are not. The real problem is the corporate-led creative marketing of unhealthy foods directed at children. Couple this with lack of exercise due to children spending countless hours on their computers (and other technological addictions) and minimal time running around, and you have the obesity problem that we have today and for the foreseeable future. Until the food industry is put under the gun like the tobacco industry, we will continue to lead the world in obesity rates.

Here's a novel thought--how about taking all the money spent on these ill-conceived campaigns, logos and pamplets and apply it to the national debt? The government minions need to get out of American kitchens, bedrooms, toy chests, pocketbooks and medicine cabinets.
I hope they hired a design company to figure this out. If it's the same entity that came up with the pyramid, it'll be another bust.

#55 DeJordy-
With all due respect I don't know any bus driver who makes $150,000. This sounds like one of those well-verified figures that Limbaugh spouts. Where are you getting your numbers? I'm an engineer who makes well under six figures working for a corporation --- you know, those great entities that the Republicans claim need even more tax breaks in order to get our economy going again and are their be-all, end-all answer to all-that-ails us --- and haven't had a pay raise for the last three years. The corporate execs are, however, getting huge bonuses. Guess there's no money left over for the rest of us who actually produce the product.

Walker and his cronies overstepped their bounds. Many of us here in Wisconsin have seen the light and will protest "like the Egytians" 'til the cows come home if need be. We are a dairy state after all!
